title: How to Bake a Two Layer Cake

steps.headline: Check the recipe and the supplies.
steps.description:
The recipe will need to provide bake times for two cakes and you'll need two 8" or 9" round pans. If you don't have two round pans and/or the recipe doesn't have bakes times for two cakes, carefully cut the cake in half with a cake leveler. If you don't have one, use a knife or something similar. Alternatively, cook the cakes separately, although this will take longer. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4a\/Bake-a-2-Layer-Cake-Step-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Bake-a-2-Layer-Cake-Step-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4a\/Bake-a-2-Layer-Cake-Step-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Bake-a-2-Layer-Cake-Step-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Bake the cake according to the recipe's directions.
Frost one piece of the cake on the top side only.
steps.description: You can use frosting, whipped cream, preserves, jelly/jam, melted marshmallows and other sweet items to spread on the cake top as filling instead. Choose whatever goes well with the flavor and texture of the cake.

steps.headline: Place the other cake on top on the filling just added.
steps.description: Do so with care, making sure it's evenly placed.

steps.headline: Frost the entire cake.
steps.description: Use whatever frosting you prefer. Alternatively, leave the cake unfrosted. The filling will already be rich enough and too much frosting can make the cake too rich to enjoy.

steps.headline: Cut and serve.
steps.description: Alternatively, wait until it's time to eat it, then cut and serve.

tyn: Frosting spatula or butter knife for spreading filling and frosting
text:
Making the cake Check the recipe and the supplies. The recipe will need to provide bake times for two cakes and you'll need two 8" or 9" round pans. If you don't have two round pans and/or the recipe doesn't have bakes times for two cakes, carefully cut the cake in half with a cake leveler. If you don't have one, use a knife or something similar. Alternatively, cook the cakes separately, although this will take longer. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4a\/Bake-a-2-Layer-Cake-Step-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Bake-a-2-Layer-Cake-Step-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4a\/Bake-a-2-Layer-Cake-Step-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Bake-a-2-Layer-Cake-Step-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Bake the cake according to the recipe's directions. Frosting and filling the cake Frost one piece of the cake on the top side only. You can use frosting, whipped cream, preserves, jelly/jam, melted marshmallows and other sweet items to spread on the cake top as filling instead. Choose whatever goes well with the flavor and texture of the cake. Place the other cake on top on the filling just added. Do so with care, making sure it's evenly placed. Frost the entire cake. Use whatever frosting you prefer. Alternatively, leave the cake unfrosted. The filling will already be rich enough and too much frosting can make the cake too rich to enjoy. Decorate as needed. Cut and serve. Alternatively, wait until it's time to eat it, then cut and serve.
sentences: Making the cake Check the recipe and the supplies.
The recipe will need to provide bake times for two cakes and you'll need two 8" or 9" round pans.
If you don't have two round pans and/or the recipe doesn't have bakes times for two cakes, carefully cut the cake in half with a cake leveler.
If you don't have one, use a knife or something similar.
Alternatively, cook the cakes separately, although this will take longer.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4a\/Bake-a-2-Layer-Cake-Step-3.jpg\/v4-460px-Bake-a-2-Layer-Cake-Step-3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4a\/Bake-a-2-Layer-Cake-Step-3.jpg\/v4-760px-Bake-a-2-Layer-Cake-Step-3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Bake the cake according to the recipe's directions.
Frosting and filling the cake Frost one piece of the cake on the top side only.
You can use frosting, whipped cream, preserves, jelly/jam, melted marshmallows and other sweet items to spread on the cake top as filling instead.
Choose whatever goes well with the flavor and texture of the cake.
Place the other cake on top on the filling just added.
Do so with care, making sure it's evenly placed.
The filling will already be rich enough and too much frosting can make the cake too rich to enjoy.
Alternatively, wait until it's time to eat it, then cut and serve.
